title: Question 96

children: A 24-year-old woman is evaluated for a 2-year history of painful menstrual periods, causing her to miss work once or twice a month. She reports no abnormal vaginal bleeding or discharge. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She is sexually active with men and uses condoms for contraception. Her last sexual intercourse was 2 months ago. She does not desire pregnancy at this time. Her last Pap smear obtained 1 year ago was normal. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable, and she takes no medications.
Physical examination, including pelvic examination, is normal.
A pregnancy test result and chlamydia screening are negative.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Management options for primary or secondary dysmenorrhea include empiric treatment with either combined hormonal contraceptives or progesterone-only methods.
NSAIDs are an effective treatment for dysmenorrhea, acting by reducing the release of prostaglandins and thereby helping to reduce cramping and menstrual blood loss.
The most appropriate management is a combined hormonal oral contraceptive pill (

). Dysmenorrhea is characterized by pain and cramping during menstruation and can be associated with low back pain, nausea, headache, and gastrointestinal symptoms. Dysmenorrhea is classified as either primary, when there is no identified cause, or secondary, for which endometriosis is the most common cause. Many women with dysmenorrhea have symptoms severe enough to result in missed school, work, or other activities. Whether primary or secondary dysmenorrhea, empiric treatment with either combined hormonal contraceptives (pill, patch, or ring) or progesterone-only methods (pill, injection, implant, or intrauterine device [IUD]) are appropriate options. Before prescribing a combined hormonal contraceptive, it is important to assess for contraindications to estrogen, including a history of venous thromboembolism or migraine with aura. In this patient without contraindications and a need for more effective contraceptive therapy, a combined hormonal oral contraceptive pill is a reasonable option.

) is often used for the treatment of dysmenorrhea; it may be more effective than placebo but is not as effective as NSAIDs. NSAIDs reduce the release of prostaglandins and thereby help reduce cramps and menstrual blood loss. Because of this patient's need for more effective contraception, a combined hormonal oral contraceptive is a more attractive option than either acetaminophen or NSAIDs.

) would not improve the patient's dysmenorrhea. Some women report heavier menstrual bleeding and increased cramping with use of the copper IUD. Levonorgestrel-releasing IUDs, however, are an effective treatment modality for women with dysmenorrhea who are interested in long-acting contraceptive options.

) is not required to diagnose or treat dysmenorrhea in the setting of a normal physical examination. Even if there is a concern for a secondary cause of dysmenorrhea, such as endometriosis, empiric treatment is recommended before initiating diagnostic studies.

references: Kho KA, Shields JK. Diagnosis and management of primary dysmenorrhea. JAMA. 2020;323:268-9.
